repo.name: neovim

body:
Goal: Make `nvim_open_win` and `nvim_win_set_config` support opening splits, and moving floating windows into splits.

Changes to `FloatConfig`:
- It is now called `WinConfig`
- Its name in the `win_T` struct is now `w_config` instead of `w_float_config` (can revert if wanted, but figured it makes sense with the WinConfig change)
- The `win` prop is now also used to determine which window should be split
  - Zero should split the current window, non-zero should split a specific window, and nil should create a top-level split.
  - A side-affect of this is that split windows can now be moved with `nvim_win_set_config`.
- Added `vertical` and `split` props for controlling split position

Additionally, `win_split_ins` now returns the `win_T*` pointer to the newly created window on success, and `NULL` on failure, as it can initialize windows and it is useful (required for this PR) to have a pointer to the new window after creating it.

**Needs Discussion**:
- Removing `relative = ""` entirely, or leaving it for compatibility
- Using `win=-1`  vs `win=nil` for top-level splits (would allow for `win=nil` to split the current window) ([related](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25550#issuecomment-1756655060))

TODO:
- [x] Tests
- [x] Docs
- [x] Create `split` prop
- [x] Add `vertical` boolean prop as an alias for `split="left"` / `split="below"`
- [x] Validation for updated win configs
- [x] Handle case of window already being a normal window
- [x] Rename `FloatConfig` to `WinConfig`
  - [x] Rename `win_T.w_float_config` to `win_T.w_config` 
- [x] Update `nvim_win_get_config`
  - [x] Add `width`, `height`, and `split` props
- [x] Non-floats should use `relative=nil`, not `relative=""`
- [x] Apply width / height props to created splits
- [ ]  Update current win split direction better in `set_config` ([see here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25550#discussion_r1368034099))
- [x] More tests
  - [x] Opening windows in non-current tabpage
  - [x] Moving windows to other tabpages
  - [x] Ensure set_config being called with the retval of get_config is a no-op

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/38540736/6a8e2d38-d0b4-4de5-bcca-e5d605f5609f

fixes #14315 (maybe)

- Matching the existing `nvim_parse_cmd` interface seems like a safe choice.

> Should omitting `relative` resolve to a split window, the same as `relative=""`?

Yes. `relative` always was meant to indicate "this is a float". So if not given then it's not a float. I'd also say we _shouldn't_ support `relative=""`. "Relative" is only for floats.

comment_data.body:
Working on this now, and I'm realizing that the behavior of the options that match `parse_cmd` is not the same as my current implementation. The current implementation allows splitting any direction from any window, but `:belowright` / `:topleft` always create top-level splits. Imo the current functionality of this PR is more predictable and flexible than this would be. Should I use the names of the `split` options but keep the current functionality? 

I think a good enum option for the current implementation would be `top`/`bottom`/`left`/`right` because that more accurately describes how the window will split. 

| split | win | resulting action |
|--------|-------|------------------------|
| top   | 0     | horizontal split above curwin |
| left   | nil   | top-level left-aligned vert split |
| right | 1002 | vertical split to the right of window 1002 |

etc...

This is The Way! This was always the intention for `nvim_open_win`. 

Obligatory mantra: one interface (`nvim_open_win`) is usually better than multiple separate interfaces (e.g. `nvim_open_float` + `nvim_open_split`) unless there is truly an "impedance mismatch" that justifies separate interfaces. One interface tends to result in less documentation (redundant documentation is a burden on both users _and_ maintainers) and less code.

One interface tends to result in less documentation (redundant documentation is a burden on both users _and_ maintainers) and less code.

Awesome! Glad this was the plan already, I just stumbled on the issue and thought it would be cool to have (and an interesting challenge). I definitely agree that a unified interface is best, especially for UI-related features that will often be customized by users.

There's also *tons* of this type of thing used in plugins (and in my [`tabpage_set_layout`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24507) implementation) that will be able to be replaced, it will be very nice to have a single way to open all kinds of windows:

```lua
local splitright = vim.o.splitright
local splitbelow = vim.o.splitbelow
vim.o.splitright = true
vim.o.splitbelow = true
vim.api.nvim_win_call(win, vim.cmd.vsplit)
vim.o.splitright = splitright
vim.o.splitbelow = splitbelow
```

`win_get_config` now returns the `split` property. There are probably still some edge cases to cover for when that property can change, but it seems to work consistently now that it is initialized in `win_split_ins` and updated in `win_close`. 

Because of this, I'll need to ensure that the split isn't changed in `set_config` if the `split` and `win` properties haven't been modified (so that reusing the same config doesn't attempt to recreate the split), but that should be trivial.

Added `width` and `height` to `win_get_config` for splits as well. 

The goal of this is and the change mentioned in my previous comment is that calling

should be a no-op.

Found a logical issue: only `nvim_open_win` will work for creating top-level windows (windows at the root of the layout tree / created with `WSP_TOP`/`WSP_BOT`), since omitting `win` and `split` will not change the split state, and setting `win` will move the split to a specific window. Maybe top-level windows should be created with `win=-1` instead of `win=nil`?
Thanks for the reviews! I'll get these doc updates in later today. Will have updates for the `split` property as well, still working on the edge cases for when `win_set_config` updates the layout.

Opinions on using `win=-1` to create top-level splits, and using `win=nil` or `win=0` for the current window? I think there's precedence for this in viml with `getcwd` taking a winid or `-1` to get the cwd of the tabpage, and imo it's a more ergonomic API as calling `nvim_open_win(0, true, {vertical=true})` would be identical to the behavior of `:vsplit` instead of requiring `nvim_open_win(0, true, {vertical=true, win=0})`.

As of 711356a, all weird cases where the split tracking breaks (that I know of) are fixed. There are likely more that I haven't found, but hopefully tests and such will help find those.

In this case it was not really an edge case to be fair, more of a skill issue on my part as I was only checking `WSP_TOP` when I needed to be checking both that and `WSP_BOT`.

I have realized that splits don't really need to be "tracked" at all, since it's trivial to determine the direction of a split when it's needed. I think I can get rid of all of the tracking logic in favor of a `win_split_dir` function which will be used by `get_config` and `set_config` to determine the current split direction.

`win = -1` now creates a top-level split, and `win = nil` creating a top-level split.
